quizzes.quizname: week five: color and the box model

questions.question_text: the following are all valid color notations on the web except...
questions.explanation: Oh, acronyms! CMYK is for print, not screen, output. There's also a fourth notation. Do you remember what it is?

questions.question_text: true or false: every color on a computer screen is created by mixing amounts of red, green, and blue.
questions.explanation: See page 251 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: the foreground and background color properties are, respectively...
questions.explanation: See pages 249–250 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: true or false: a background color is visible in an element’s margin.
questions.explanation: Background colors are only visible in the space an element occupies and its padding. Margin is always transparent, revealing any content behind, or under, it.

questions.question_text: the box model encompasses the following properties except:
questions.explanation: The box-sizing property name is a red herring. See page 307 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: all of the following about borders are true except...

answers.answer_text: an element can have different borders on each of its sides
a border line can have one of multiple styles, including solid, dashed, and dotted lines
a border can incorporate an image in lieu of a line
a border can have its own padding

questions.explanation: The “correct” answer makes no sense. An element can have padding, but a border does not have padding.

questions.question_text: true or false: the margin property can have positive and negative values.
questions.explanation: True! margin can have negative values, but padding cannot. This is useful for slightly overlapping elements.

questions.explanation: There's a visibility property in CSS, but even invisible isn't one of its valid values! See page 317 in HTML & CSS for details.
